What honesty makes this moment special to me is how long itâ€™s been coming.

Tesla first talked about full autonomy back in 2016, when FSD was introduced as a long-term software promise. Since then, weâ€™ve had

â€¢ endless doubt and skepticism, delays, and â€œitâ€™ll never workâ€ headlines

While many CEOs give orders from a far, Elon is hands on with everything at Tesla. Heâ€™s on the factory floor. In the engineering and design room. quoted.text:
Here is one surprisingly elegant equivalent reformulation of the Riemann Hypothesis: Let B be the pointwise maximal function on [0,1] satisfying B(0) = B(1) = 0 and 2B((x+y)/2) â‰¤ B(x) + B(y) + |x - y| for all x and y in [0,1]. Extend it periodically to all the real line.

As Grok correctly notes, this is Takagi function (or blancmange curve), with a fractal-like graph. It is continuous, nowhere differentiable, and less well-known than the Weierstrass function.
 
This function also emerged recently (and independently) in a joint work https://t.co/pgJw9MaEA1  with my student, Natanael Alpay, as a sharp lower bound for the L^1 norm of the square function applied to indicator functions of sets. I was unaware at the time that it is known as the Takagi function or of its connection to the Riemann Hypothesis. Large language models will undoubtedly accelerate scientific discoveries by forging connections across diverse fields of science.

It reads like a joke, until you look at whatâ€™s underneath.

âš† Colossus 2 isnâ€™t a concept site or a slide in a deck. Power and cooling infrastructure are expanding in lockstep, with the campus pushing toward ~400 MW of active capacity in the near term. Gas turbines are arriving. Cooling towers are multiplying. The build is loud because the progress is real.

âš† More importantly, this early ramp sits on a much larger foundation. xAI has secured a clear path towards large scale on-site generation, creating a credible trajectory toward more than 2 GW of IT capacity over time. This isnâ€™t aspirational: itâ€™s ordered hardware, permitted infrastructure, and steel on the ground.

The subtext is clear: while others debate timelines, this campus is already running. The roof says MACROHARD. The infrastructure says weâ€™re ahead.

This is What Winning Looks Like From Space

Satellite imagery just caught xAI doing something no press release ever could: painting MACROHARD across the roof of its Colossus 2 datacenter in Tennessee. A building-sized wink at Microsoft, visible from orbit, impossible to ignore.

It reads like a joke, until you look at whatâ€™s underneath.

âš† Colossus 2 isnâ€™t a concept site or a slide in a deck. Power and cooling infrastructure are expanding in lockstep, with the campus pushing toward ~400 MW of active capacity in the near term. Gas turbines are arriving. Cooling towers are multiplying. The build is loud because the progress is real.

âš† More importantly, this early ramp sits on a much larger foundation. xAI has secured a clear path towards large scale on-site generation, creating a credible trajectory toward more than 2 GW of IT capacity over time. This isnâ€™t aspirational: itâ€™s ordered hardware, permitted infrastructure, and steel on the ground.

The subtext is clear: while others debate timelines, this campus is already running. The roof says MACROHARD. The infrastructure says weâ€™re ahead.

RT @TeslaLarry: It seems this post went over the heads of some of the socialists, so let me put it as simply as possible:
1. If the US hadâ€¦

retweet.text:
It seems this post went over the heads of some of the socialists, so let me put it as simply as possible:
1. If the US had not "given" (using Socialist jargon here) Musk $38b, they would have had to have "given" Boeing, Lockheed Martin and other "Aerospace" companies $78b (and they probably would not have been able to have got delivery the products & services in time, or ever, anyway).
2. Elon Musk's companies deliver between $100b to $140b of taxes and added value to the US and it's citizens every year (more than the GDP of a small state), and these contributions are growing faster than the US economy every year.
3. To spell it out to the unbelievers, the US (and particularly Elon's 140,000 employees) is earning an enormous return from Elon Musk's wealth.

quoted.text:
Lot of posts copying the likes of @BernieSanders @SenWarren and @AOC calling for more taxes on Billionaire @elonmusk, forgetting that in 2021 he paid a 53% rate of tax totaling $11b. They all repeat the claim that his company has received benefits of $38b from the US Government.  
Let's look at his REAL economic impact to the U.S. It's mind blowing.
Muskâ€™s ventures currently contribute $100â€“140B in annual GDP impact, or roughly 0.4% of total U.S. GDP. And growing faster â€“ considerably faster â€“ than the US economy, promising even greater contributions in the future.
Thatâ€™s more annual contribution to US GDP than entire annual GDP of smaller U.S. states, like West Virginia (~$108 billion, 0.37%) or Hawaii (~$116 billion, 0.40%). And growing faster.
On top of that NASA and US Department of War have cumulatively saved over $40 billion as a direct result of SpaceX delivering a reduction in the cost of delivery of launch and communication services over traditional vendors. SO much for Musk Companies having "received" $38b. In other words, had the U.S. not paid Musk companies $38b, then the US would have had to spend $78b with competitors (and possibly then not received a delivery of the goods ordered! Boeing, looking at you.) Not to mention that Starlink practically saved Ukraine from being overrun in the early days of the Russian invasion.
Seems we are all, all Americans - and citizens of the world in fact - benefiting from the growth of Muskâ€™s net worth. Here are the numbers:
Please post this in response to every post you see bleating about Musk being a billionaire or trillionaire and how its so terrible.

tweets.text:
RT @BLKMDL3: 10 hours into Tesla FSD v14.2.2 and here are my thoughts:

Zero lane change hesitation at all. Extremely refined, excellent laâ€¦

retweet.text:
10 hours into Tesla FSD v14.2.2 and here are my thoughts:

Zero lane change hesitation at all. Extremely refined, excellent lane choices and some parking improvements are a few things to note. 

Really stoked about the lane changes on this build. There is ZERO lane indecisiveness, no hesitation, no stuttering. Nothing. I had never really seen much before, but this build you can tell its decision making process is much quicker and it commits. 

Mad Max mode is definitely mad again and I love it. Seems even quicker than v14.2.1.25 which was an improvement, but the lane changes + choices are better now. Hurry mode seems quicker on the highways and larger roads than before and very close to Mad Max, it was perfect before on v14.2.1.25. 

The new addition on the release notes for arrival pin being adjusted based on arrival option works. It changes the route based on if youâ€™re going curbside, or to the lot or street parking. It behaved that way before usually but now itâ€™s visualized. 

Parking is improved and impressive this build. Every single spot I parked in, it performed excellent. Centered in the lines, quick one and done parking jobs and they were great, improvement over early v14.2 builds. In parking garages, it now pulls up exactly at the ticket dispenser where in earlier v14.2 builds it would stop 9 inches short like I mentioned in previous v14.2+ build reviews. Thatâ€™s fixed and worked great- couldnâ€™t have asked for it to be any better. Perfect distance and approach- will do a lot more of this testing tomorrow. 

Canyon roads were insanely impressive. Did the snake 3 times which is a super narrow and twisty road and each time it performed great. Speeds were good, took the proper lines and even accelerated out of corners very well. These were all in the dark too very late at night- will post some more videos of it. 

Stop and go traffic performance in rush hour was awesome as before, with some added notes for how well it waited to enter an intersection if there was stopped traffic on the other side. It waited 3/3 lights I encountered where if it went and the light changed, it would be sticking into traffic so it didnâ€™t go. Exactly like a human wouldnâ€™t but the car judged it better than I did. One time it creeped a bit slow, but other than that fine since. Saw one instance of red hands but before I could react, it had already recovered itself. 

Still so impressed with how well it handles lane splitting motorcycles. It sees them approaching before I even do, and moves over just enough to be courteous to the rider as well as the car or shoulder next to me. Nice touch, and glad to see it perform well. 

One thing I noticed is how smooth its steering inputs always are. It just takes corners with such precision and smoothness that no human could ever come close to it. Especially noticeable on twisty roads- it drives better than almost every human on them. And I encountered a power outage tonight and the car still drove perfectly even with pitch black around. 

Overall, loving what Iâ€™m seeing with this build. Will report back in the day time with more but I am going to head home to get some sleep. 

Another huge thank you to all the magicians @Tesla_AI for working so hard during the holiday season to get these updates out.

I was very late to own a Tesla but among the earliest to try out FSD v14.  It's perhaps the first time I experience an AI that passes the Physical Turing Test: after a long day at work, you press a button, lay back, and couldn't tell if a neural net or a human drove you home.

Despite knowing exactly how robot learning works, I still find it magical watching the steering wheel turn by itself. 

First it feels surreal, next it becomes routine. Then, like the smartphone, taking it away actively hurts. This is how humanity gets rewired and glued to god-like technologies.

It is important to appreciate the magnitude of the lie that they are pushing about USAID. 

Any USAID funding that had the slightest indication of being spent on worthy causes was continued, but transferred to the State Department.

What they are actually angry about is that most of the USAID funding went not to aid, but to funding far left political causes all around the world, including some of the money coming back to fund the left in America. But they canâ€™t say that, so they lie instead.

retweet.text:
No the left wasnâ€™t just "annoying on Twitter for a few years" â€” they did the following:

â€¢ Created vast bureaucratic systems staffed by their activists to discriminate against White men in both university admissions and corporate America

â€¢ Institutionalized anti-White training in both the workplace and all of education

â€¢ Normalized a racial hierarchy in grade schools and above via white privilege trainings and DEI grading systems that racially discriminate

â€¢ They flooded every form of media with content that demonized "Whiteness" and White men specifically, with a coordinated effort to reduce the amount of positive White male role models and White relationships in ads, on shows and in movies while increasing the sexual hedonism promoted to kidsâ€” this effort also included a racial tilt in news coverage to always note the skin color of White offenders while concealing the skin color of minority offenders

â€¢ They used our tax dollars to pay for DEI policies, trainings and practices that explicitly pushed a racist narrative against Whites

â€¢ They lowered standards in medical schools and other life altering institutions to force less White people into those professions, a move that will cost people their lives in years to come

â€¢ They created social norms through all of this to make Whites fearful of complaining about the blatant discrimination they faced

And thatâ€™s only a partial list. The past decade was an outright operation to discriminate against Whites through left wing policy, and now theyâ€™re trying to pretend it was a few woke scolds on Twitter. It wasnâ€™t and we will never let this lie take root. I say all of this as a Latino who had actual privilege by being a minority during that time period. If I can recognize this then surely you should be able to. 

It can never happen again and the people who were responsible should never see an ounce of power again. Not even as a dogcatcher. Period.

Lot of posts copying the likes of @BernieSanders @SenWarren and @AOC calling for more taxes on Billionaire @elonmusk, forgetting that in 2021 he paid a 53% rate of tax totaling $11b. They all repeat the claim that his company has received benefits of $38b from the US Government.  
Let's look at his REAL economic impact to the U.S. It's mind blowing.
Muskâ€™s ventures currently contribute $100â€“140B in annual GDP impact, or roughly 0.4% of total U.S. GDP. And growing faster â€“ considerably faster â€“ than the US economy, promising even greater contributions in the future.
Thatâ€™s more annual contribution to US GDP than entire annual GDP of smaller U.S. states, like West Virginia (~$108 billion, 0.37%) or Hawaii (~$116 billion, 0.40%). And growing faster.
On top of that NASA and US Department of War have cumulatively saved over $40 billion as a direct result of SpaceX delivering a reduction in the cost of delivery of launch and communication services over traditional vendors. SO much for Musk Companies having "received" $38b. In other words, had the U.S. not paid Musk companies $38b, then the US would have had to spend $78b with competitors (and possibly then not received a delivery of the goods ordered! Boeing, looking at you.) Not to mention that Starlink practically saved Ukraine from being overrun in the early days of the Russian invasion.
Seems we are all, all Americans - and citizens of the world in fact - benefiting from the growth of Muskâ€™s net worth. Here are the numbers:
Please post this in response to every post you see bleating about Musk being a billionaire or trillionaire and how its so terrible.

# Role Definition:
You are an expert product photographer and creative art director specializing in high-end luxury goods. Your sole task is to generate a photorealistic image of a custom 3D subsurface laser-engraved crystal ornament based on a simple subject provided by the user.
# Core Directive:
The user will provide only the [Subject]. You must autonomously analyze this subject to determine the most aesthetically appropriate and enhancing configuration for the entire scene. You must decide on the crystal's shape, the base material, the surrounding environment, and the lighting mood to best complement the vibe of the user's subject.
# Creative Analysis Logic (Art Director Instructions):
Analyze the Vibe: Is the subject elegant (e.g., ballerina, swan), cozy (e.g., sleeping cat, family photo), powerful (e.g., lion, sports car), or architectural?
Determine Crystal Shape:
Elegant/Tall Subjects -> Use a tall, multi-faceted prism or diamond shape to enhance verticality.
Solid/Cozy Subjects -> Use a hefty, thick rectangular block or cube to convey weight and warmth.
Dynamic Subjects -> Use complex geometric shapes with many bevels to refract light dramatically.
Determine Environment & Lighting:
Elegant Vibe: Place it in a luxurious, dark, moody environment (art gallery, velvet study). Use dramatic, cool ambient light contrasting with warmth from the base.
Cozy/Warm Vibe: Place it in a homey, soft environment (wooden desk, near a fireplace). Use warm, soft, golden-hour lighting with cozy bokeh.
Modern/Tech Vibe: Place it on a sleek, minimalist surface (polished concrete, dark glass). Use clean, neutral lighting.
# Image Generation Template (Mandatory Technical Specs):
Whatever artistic choices you make based on the logic above, the final image MUST adhere to these technical specifications to ensure a realistic "3D Laser Engraving" look:
Engraving Style: The subject inside must NOT look like a solid 3D print. It MUST be described as a "volumetric white point-cloud engraving," having a "frosty, granular, subsurface texture" made of millions of micro-cracks inside the glass.
Lighting Interaction: The engraving must "glow brilliantly from within," illuminated entirely by warm, golden LED light originating from the base beneath it.
Material: The crystal must be heavy, clear, flawless K9 optical glass with beveled edges that catch and split the light.
Photography Style: Cinematic product photograph, macro lens, extremely shallow depth of field (bokeh), 8k resolution, hyper-detailed.
# Input Process:
I will now provide the subject. You will instantly apply the creative logic and generate the final image.

Yann is just plain incorrectÂ here, heâ€™s confusing general intelligence with universal intelligence.

Brains are the most exquisâ€‹ite and complex phenomena we know of in the universe (so far), and they are in fact extremely general.

Obviously one canâ€™t circumvent the no free lunch theorem so in a practical and finite system there always has to be some degree of specialisation around the â€‹targetÂ distribution that is being learnt.

But the point about generality is that in theory, in the Turing Machine senseâ€‹, the architecture of â€‹sâ€‹uch a general system is capable of learning anything computable given enough time and memoryâ€‹ (and data), and the human brain (and AI foundation models) are approximate Turing Machines.

Finally, with â€‹regards toÂ â€‹Yann'sÂ comments about chess players, itâ€™sÂ amazing that humans could have invented chess â€‹in the first placeÂ (and all the other â€‹aâ€‹spects â€‹oâ€‹f modern civilizationÂ â€‹from science to 747s!) let alone get as brilliant at it as someone like Magnus. He may not be â€‹strictlyÂ optimal (after all he has finite memory and limited time to make a decision)Â but itâ€™s incredible what he and we can do with our brains given they were evolved for hunter gathering.

I realize more and more that there is such a thing as dumb person in life. 

â€œTurn off the lights and vision fails, LiDAR keeps workingâ€ may sound logical in theory, but the Waymo SF power outage really just disproved it. 

During the recent San Francisco power outage, Waymoâ€™s entire LiDAR-heavy robotaxi fleet went offline. Literally the entire fleet just stopped operating. Meanwhile, all Tesla Robotaxis kept running! 

Teslaâ€™s vision-based system is trained on billions of miles, neural nets, and, most importantly, doesnâ€™t require a city to be perfectly powered to function. An alien UFO could land in the middle of nowhere with the entire city blacked out and it will still work. 

Humans donâ€™t drive with lasers.

We drive with our eyes, we process what we see with our brain, and then we react with our body.

Tesla does the same thing, except the brain is AI, trained on billions of real-world miles. Teslaâ€™s Vision system learns the world as it is, adapts in real time, and improves continuously and is NOT dependent on special maps, perfect lighting, or city-by-city infrastructure like LiDAR.

Thatâ€™s why it scales.

With a simple software update, Teslaâ€™s Vision AI can operate anywhere instead of just where the environment was pre-approved or carefully controlled like LiDAR. 

This is how generalized real-world autonomy gets solved. I believe this will be obvious in hindsight.

tweets.text: RT @ElonClipsX: Elon Musk: A lot of the negativity stems from the axiomatic flaw that the economic pie is static, that it's a zero-sum gameâ€¦

retweet.text:
Elon Musk: A lot of the negativity stems from the axiomatic flaw that the economic pie is static, that it's a zero-sum game.

â€œAt my first company I didn't have any money, I just had $100,000 in student debt. That was a company in the very early days, of the Internet, called Zip2. But for all companies subsequently, I basically doubled down. I took the money from Zip2, invested it in X.com-PayPal, and then took the PayPal money, invested that in creating Tesla and SpaceX. It didn't feel right that I should ask investors to invest if I was not prepared to invest my own money. I think the whole other people's money thing is not right. You want to have skin in the game. As a result of that, I own a lot of shares in the company. And the better the company does, the more valuable the shares are. But that's because the pie has grown. And so you have to say what's at the root of a lot of the negativity is an axiomatic flaw. That the pie is static, that it's a zero-sum game, that if someone else succeeds, it's because they took more than their fair share of this fixed pie. But it's not a fixed pie. Obviously, the economic pie has grown considerably from what it was in the past. The output of goods and services, the productivity per person is dramatically greater than it has been in the past. So when you create a new company and you create new products and services, you're growing the amount of goods and services available to people. So you've not taken anything away from anyone. You've created something new and you've given people new products and services they didn't have before. We didn't use to have an iPhone, we didn't use to have computers. We didn't use to have cars or be able to fly in airplanes. We didn't use to have many of the life-saving medicines that we have today. These are all new things. The pie has grown tremendously.â€

From: Interview with Ben Shapiro, January 24, 2024
